questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of nasal symptoms. He has had nasal itching, sneezing and congestion most days of the week for the last six weeks. He awakens with a sore throat each morning and occasionally has mild facial pressure over the maxillary sinuses. He has not had a fever, chills, or sweats. He develops similar symptoms every spring and fall and reports needing antibiotics twice per year. Symptoms are not affecting his quality of life or sleep. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 122/72 mmHg. On examination, the nasal turbinates appear edematous with a bluish hue bilaterally. And clear rhinorrhea is present. There is no tenderness over the maxillary sinuses. Cobble stoning is present in the posterior pharynx without tonsillar hypertrophy, erythema, or exudate. Tympanic membranes are intact without effusion or redness. Which of the following is the best initial treatment option?
questions.solution:
This patient can be diagnosed with mild persistent allergic rhinitis based on having symptoms more than four days per week for more than four weeks a year, that do not affect his quality of life. The first line treatment for patients with allergic rhinitis is a glucocorticoid nasal spray, such as fluticasone propionate.         

Patients with allergic rhinitis should be encouraged to avoid known triggers when possible and to use saline nasal irrigation to clear debris and allergens. Beyond supportive care, several pharmacological therapies can be helpful. The most effective pharmacologic treatment for allergic rhinitis is intranasal steroids. When these cannot be tolerated or are ineffective, intranasal antihistamines serve as a helpful adjunct and can be used alone or in combination with a nasal steroid. The addition of an oral antihistamine to a nasal steroid has not been shown to provide clear benefits over steroids alone. An oral decongestant may be needed when allergic rhinitis is severe, meaning that it significantly impacts the patient’s quality of life. The leukotriene receptor antagonist, montelukast, can be prescribed in patients who also have asthma. If environmental control measures have been maximized and the patient is experiencing significant symptoms despite an optimal medication regimen, immunotherapy can be considered. Allergen-specific testing is not necessary in the routine workup of allergic rhinitis unless immunotherapy is being considered, or when the causative agent cannot be readily identified.    

Option Analysis

✅ Fluticasone propionate nasal spray:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Azelastine nasal spray :
Incorrect: Azelastine is an antihistamine nasal spray which can provide additional symptom relief when glucocorticoid nasal sprays are not tolerated or ineffective. Glucocorticoid nasal sprays are a first line treatment for allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Oxymetazoline nasal spray:
Incorrect: Oxymetazoline nasal spray is a topical decongestant which can cause a form of rebound nasal congestion called rhinitis medicamentosa when used for more than 72 hours at a time. Oxymetazoline has limited usefulness in the temporary relief of nasal congestion and should not be recommended for ongoing therapy in allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Montelukast:
Incorrect: Montelukast, a leukotriene receptor antagonist, can be helpful in the treatment of allergic rhinitis, especially in patients with a history of asthma. This patient does not have a history of asthma and Glucocorticoid nasal sprays are first-line therapy for allergic rhinitis.  
❌ Azithromycin:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are indicated when there is evidence of allergic rhinitis plus a secondary bacterial infection such as bacterial sinusitis or otitis media. This patient does not currently have signs of a secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of nasal congestion. His parent reports the patient has had nasal congestion and an evening cough for two weeks. The patient’s three-year-old brother had similar symptoms that have since resolved. The patient was improving, but four days ago, he developed worsening nasal discharge and fever to 39.2°C (102.6°F). His parent has not noticed a change in appetite. The patient has not had a sore throat, ear pain, or headache. He is otherwise healthy. Current temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 128/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/71 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for edematous and erythematous nasal turbinates, and purulent mucus is visualized in the posterior nasopharynx. The pediatrician suspects acute bacterial sinusitis. This infection most likely spread to which of the following anatomic spaces?
questions.solution:
The nasal cavity has numerous connections to its surrounding spaces. It is important to remember the relationship between the nasal cavity and its surrounding structures because nasal congestion can cause inflammation and swelling of the mucosa close to the openings of these spaces. When the surrounding spaces are unable to drain properly, infection can develop and spread.

In particular, the maxillary sinuses are the most common site to which an infection in the nasal cavity might spread. The openings (or ostia) to the maxillary sinuses are small and can be easily obstructed when the surrounding nasal mucosa becomes congested. Also, because of the orientation of the maxillary sinuses in the skull, it is difficult for them to drain properly when the head is upright or lying on one side; the ostia are directed towards one another, so when lying on the side, only the top sinus can actually drain.  



Option Analysis

❌ Frontal sinus  :
Incorrect: The frontal sinus is located in the frontal bone and opens into the anterior part of the middle meatus via the frontonasal duct. While it is possible for an infection to reach the frontal sinuses, the maxillary sinuses are a more common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Anterior ethmoidal cells:
Incorrect: Anterior ethmoidal cells drain directly or indirectly into the middle nasal meatus through the ethmoidal infundibulum. The anterior ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Middle ethmoidal cells  :
Incorrect: The middle ethmoidal cells open directly into the middle meatus and are called “bullar cells”  because they form the ethmoidal bulla–a swelling over the superior border of the semilunar hiatus. The middle ethmoidal cells are not a common site of spread from a nasal cavity infection.  
❌ Sphenoidal sinus  :
Incorrect: The sphenoid sinus lies inferior to the sella turcica and communicates with the nasal cavity via the sphenoethmoidal recess. It is an uncommon site of sinus infection.
✅ Maxillary sinus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is evaluated on inpatient rounds for a retropharyngeal abscess. Temperature is 102 °F, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 20/min. The patient is awake and oriented and appears tired. He is not struggling to breathe and is otherwise resting comfortably. An area of erythematous inflammation is seen in the posterior oropharynx, and the patient has mild submandibular lymphadenopathy. Parenteral antibiotic therapy is initiated with clindamycin and metronidazole. The physician explains to the parents at the bedside that urgent treatment is required due to the potential spread of infection into a region called the “danger space.” Which of the following best describes the boundaries of this space?

choices.text: Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly
Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly
Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly

questions.solution:
Posterior to the pharynx, there is a potential space called the retropharyngeal space. This space is bounded anteriorly by the buccopharyngeal fascia, the superior continuation of the pretracheal fascia, and posteriorly by the alar fascia. Infection in the retropharyngeal space can also lead to a retropharyngeal abscess, resulting in difficulty swallowing and speaking.

Another important space is the ‘danger space,’ which is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral layer of the deep cervical fascia. This space extends from the base of the skull into the posterior mediastinum and down to the level of the diaphragm, making it the most important route for the spread of infection between the neck and thorax.



Option Analysis

❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: These are the boundaries of the retropharyngeal space. The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Buccopharyngeal fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
❌ Pretracheal fascia anteriorly and alar fascia posteriorly:
Incorrect: The ‘danger space’ is posterior to the retropharyngeal space and bounded anteriorly by the alar fascia and posteriorly by the prevertebral fascia.  
✅ Alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a sore throat. The patient was treated as an outpatient for strep throat based on clinical findings without strep testing, one week ago, but she has not had improvement in symptoms despite taking amoxicillin as prescribed. She has a history of allergic rhinitis controlled with a nasal steroid spray. She is sexually active with one male partner. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 131/67 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals erythema and swelling of the tonsils with exudates bilaterally. Cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Heterophile antibody testing, and rapid influenza testing are negative. Rapid strep is negative, and gram stain comes back positive for gram-negative cocci. NAAT is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with pharyngitis that has been unresponsive to initial empiric therapy targeted against Streptococcus sp. Given that the patient is sexually active and has gram-negative cocci isolated from the throat, she likely has gonococcal pharyngitis and should be treated with intramuscular ceftriaxone.        

Pharyngitis or inflammation of the pharynx can be caused by non-infectious conditions, like allergic rhinitis, as well as viral and bacterial infections. Treatment of pharyngitis depends on the likely underlying cause. Non-infectious causes such as allergic pharyngitis and pharyngitis caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease can be treated with antihistamines and acid-reducing medications, respectively. Viral pharyngitis is typically self-limited and will resolve without intervention. The level of care needed for pharyngitis caused by bacteria is dependent on the location and severity of the infection. Pharyngitis caused by Group A Streptococcus can be treated with oral antibiotics, while parenteral antibiotic therapy is preferred for infections caused by Gonococcal species. If it is caused by bacterial infection and there is an associated fluid collection (peritonsillar or retropharyngeal abscess), the airway may be threatened, and drainage, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and surgical consultation are typically necessary.        

Option Analysis

✅ Intramuscular ceftriaxone:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid will not provide appropriate coverage for treatment of gonococcal pharyngitis. This patient requires therapy with high dose ceftriaxone. 
❌ Oseltamivir:
Incorrect: Patients with influenza can present with a sore throat, typically along with nasal congestion, cough, and fever. However, this patient tested negative for influenza. Therefore, there is no indication of treatment with oseltamivir. 
❌ Dexamethasone:
Incorrect: While dexamethasone may provide symptomatic relief for pharyngitis, it will not treat the likely underlying gonococcal infection, for which antibiotics are needed. 
❌ Cetirizine:
Incorrect: Cetirizine is an antihistamine appropriate for treating allergic rhinitis. However, this sexually active patient with findings consistent with gonococcal pharyngitis and gram stain positive for gram-negative cocci should be treated with ceftriaxone.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to a rapidly enlarging neck mass and increased difficulty in breathing over the past 6 hours. According to the parents, the child awoke with mild neck swelling that progressively increased throughout the day. The child has become increasingly irritable and is having difficulty swallowing. He has not consumed any food has been consumed since breakfast, and the parents report increased drooling. There is no history of trauma or recent upper respiratory illness. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Respiratory rate is 52/min. The child appears cyanotic. A mass is visible on the left lateral aspect of the neck, extending from the angle of the mandible to the clavicle. The overlying skin is taut but not erythematous. Inspiratory stridor and suprasternal and intercostal retractions are observed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the neck
Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels

questions.solution:
This 3-year-old child with a rapidly enlarging neck mass is clinically unstable with signs of airway compromise, including inspiratory stridor, retractions, drooling, and hypoxia. These findings indicate the need for urgent airway stabilization before any diagnostic testing or treatment can be safely performed. The airway should be secured via endotracheal intubation as soon as possible, ideally by the most experienced provider available.

The initial approach to a pediatric head or neck mass begins with an ABCDE assessment to determine clinical stability. Signs of instability include stridor, drooling, retractions, hypoxia, altered mental status, and poor perfusion. In such cases, immediate management should focus on securing the airway, providing oxygen, establishing intravenous access, and initiating continuous vital sign monitoring.

Imaging and diagnostic workup must be deferred until the patient is stable. In a stable patient, with normal breathing, oxygenation, perfusion, and mental status, a focused history and physical exam should be performed to guide the differential diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the neck:
Incorrect: CT imaging requires patient transport and supine positioning, which may precipitate respiratory decompensation in the setting of potential airway obstruction. Imaging can be pursued once the airway is secured and the patient is stable.
✅ Emergent endotracheal intubation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Empiric intravenous (IV) antibiotics:
Incorrect: Although appropriate in suspected deep neck infections, antibiotics do not address the immediate threat of airway obstruction. Definitive airway management must precede antimicrobial therapy in this unstable patient.
❌ Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) and free T4 levels:
Incorrect: Thyroid function testing is not indicated in the acute setting of respiratory distress. These studies are useful for outpatient evaluation of stable patients with suspected thyroid pathology, which typically presents with a midline neck mass.
❌ Needle aspiration of the mass:
Incorrect: Invasive procedures in a child with an unstable airway may worsen the obstruction due to bleeding or edema. Aspiration may be considered after airway stabilization in patients with fluctuant masses consistent with abscesses.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her parents for the evaluation of a sore throat, poor appetite, and malaise for the past two days. The patient’s mother reports that several of her classmates are out sick due to similar symptoms for the past two weeks. Immunizations are up to date and past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination shows bilateral tonsillar exudative infiltrates with enlarged erythematous tonsils. Anterior cervical nodes are enlarged and tender on palpation. Rapid streptococcal antigen testing is positive. Which of the following is the best next step for the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give single dose of intramuscular penicillin G
Give oral penicillin V for ten days
Give intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks

questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from pharyngitis due to group A Streptococcal infection (Streptococcus pyogenes) and the preferred oral therapy is with penicillin V for ten days. Its use in streptococcal pharyngitis is associated with a reduced risk of subsequent acute rheumatic fever (ARF). Moreover, prevention of streptococcal infections (usually with benzathine penicillin once each month for several years) in persons who have had rheumatic fever is also important to prevent the recurrence of the disease. Other indications for penicillin G and V include:  
  •  Syphilis: It is the treatment of choice for all stages of syphilis (also used for prophylaxis of recent sexual partners) 
  •  β-Hemolytic Streptococcal Toxic Shock and Necrotizing Fasciitis: Penicillin is used in combination with clindamycin 
  •  Pneumococcal pneumonia and meningitis: only for parenteral therapy of sensitive isolates of pneumococci 
  •  Pulmonary and periodontal infections by anaerobes 
  •  Actinomycosis 
  •  Clostridial gas gangrene in combination with clindamycin 


Option Analysis

❌ Give single dose of intramuscular penicillin G:
Incorrect: Single-dose intramuscular (IM) penicillin G can be administered in patients with a history of acute rheumatic fever or in patients who are non-adherent to the initial medication regimen.
✅ Give oral penicillin V for ten days:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Give intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks:
Incorrect: Intramuscular penicillin G once weekly for three weeks is the treatment regimen for tertiary syphilis, which can manifest as gummas (granulomatous disease of the skin and subcutaneous tissues, bones, or viscera) or cardiovascular involvement in sexually active adults.
❌ Supportive care only:
Incorrect: Although supportive care measures (NSAIDs or acetaminophen) may be administered to relieve fever and pain, antibiotic treatment with penicillin is the mainstay of care and prophylaxis against acute rheumatic fever.
❌ Give erythromycin for 14 days:
Incorrect: Erythromycin is the treatment of choice in patients with diphtheria pharyngitis. In contrast to group A Streptococcal pharyngitis, which has an acute onset, the onset of symptoms in diphtheria is usually gradual, beginning with mild pharyngeal injection and erythema. The hallmark of diphtheria is the formation of a tightly adherent gray membrane in the nares and throat (which is absent in this patient).

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy comes to the clinic for a routine annual health check-up. His past medical history includes asthma and allergic rhinitis. The patient uses an albuterol inhaler, a corticosteroid inhaler, and oral corticosteroids. He has not traveled out of the country recently. Family history is noncontributory. The patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. Oral examination reveals white lesions on the tongue and posterior pharynx. These lesions bleed after scraping them with a tongue depressor. An antifungal agent is initiated that binds to ergosterol in fungal cell walls to create micropores. Which of the following is the most likely pharmacological agent used in the treatment of this patient?


Reproduced from Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with oropharyngeal white plaques that bleed when scraped, suggestive of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Patients who use corticosteroid inhalers are at increased risk of acquiring an oral candidal infection. Other high-risk groups include immunocompromised patients, those with dentures, infants, and those treated with radiation/chemotherapy to the head/neck.    

Nystatin is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane to create micropores, which alters fungal cell permeability and subsequent cell death.    

Oral “swish and swallow” nystatin preparations are used for the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. Topical formulations are useful in the treatment of vulvovaginal candidiasis and for diaper rashes. It can also be used topically for corneal, conjunctival, and cutaneous candidiasis. Adverse effects associated with nystatin use include nausea, abdominal pain, vomiting, and diarrhea.  



Option Analysis

❌ Griseofulvin :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oral candidiasis. 
❌ Ketoconazole :
Incorrect: Ketoconazole is a topically administered azole indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. It targets the fungal cell membrane and blocks lanosterol synthesis.
✅ Nystatin :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Caspofungin:
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit fungal cell wall synthesis. Indications for use include esophageal candidiasis and invasive aspergillosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of oropharyngeal candidiasis. 
❌ Amphotericin B :
Incorrect: Amphotericin B does target the fungal cell membrane and create micropores, but it is not the treatment of choice for patients with oropharyngeal candidiasis due to the systemic toxicity associated with its use.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy presents to the clinic for evaluation of worsening sore throat for one week. He was diagnosed with strep throat one week ago and has been compliant with the prescribed amoxicillin; however, he has had progressive worsening of the sore throat and developed pain with swallowing and a hoarse voice two days ago. He has no significant past medical history and is up-to-date on immunizations. Temperature is 38.4°C (101°F), blood pressure is 110/67 mmHg, pulse is 111/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is seated comfortably. Mucous membranes are moist. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals erythema with significant swelling of the right tonsil with uvular deviation to the left. There is full range of motion of the neck with minimal bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Consult the surgical team for needle aspiration
Obtain computed tomography of the neck
Administer amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and discharge home

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a worsening sore throat, odynophagia (i.e., pain with swallowing) and a hoarse voice after a recent diagnosis of strep pharyngitis. On exam, there is fever and unilateral tonsillar swelling with uvular deviation, consistent with peritonsillar abscess. Diagnosis of a peritonsillar abscess can be made clinically. Acute management involves drainage of the fluid collection, typically via needle aspiration (or incision and drainage), followed by administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics.         
Pharyngitis (inflammation of the pharynx) can be caused by non-infectious conditions, like allergic rhinitis, or by viral and bacterial infections. Pharyngitis is a common pediatric condition that is easy to treat, but, in rare cases, it can progress to complications, such as peritonsillar or retropharyngeal abscess.        

The first step in management of patients with suspected pharyngitis with complications, involves assessment of the airway, breathing, and circulation. Patients should be assessed for signs of impending respiratory failure such as the tripod position, drooling, trismus, stridor, or increased work of breathing. Patients with any of these findings should have close airway monitoring, supplemental airway support (e.g., O2) and intubation and mechanical ventilation as needed.        

If patients are stable, acute management depends on the underlying cause of symptoms. If a fluid collection has developed around the tonsil (i.e., peritonsillar abscess), drainage is required in addition to antibiotics. Patients with suspected deep space infection with a retropharyngeal abscess require radiographic evaluation that may include lateral neck radiographs and/or computed tomography (CT) of the neck with contrast. Surgical consultation and broad-spectrum antibiotics are necessary for management.    

Option Analysis

✅ Consult the surgical team for needle aspiration:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Obtain computed tomography of the neck:
Incorrect: Computed tomography of the soft tissues of the neck is not routinely indicated in the work-up for patients with suspected uncomplicated peritonsillar abscess. This patient has classic findings of the condition and diagnosis can be made clinically based on the presence of tonsillar swelling and uvular deviation.  
❌ Administer dexamethasone and discharge home:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a peritonsillar abscess, which requires prompt drainage either by needle aspiration or incision and drainage. While dexamethasone may provide symptomatic relief, it will not treat the underlying condition, which could result in deep space infection and sepsis.  
❌ Administer amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and discharge home:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a peritonsillar abscess, which requires prompt drainage. While antibiotic therapy is indicated, it will not provide adequate source control of the infection, and drainage is also needed.  
❌  Intubate in the operating room:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of a peritonsillar abscess, which requires prompt needle aspiration or incision and drainage. This patient has no evidence of airway compromise nor are there clinical findings to suggest epiglottitis (e.g., stridor, tripod position) which would require intubation.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of a sore throat and neck pain. The patient had a viral upper respiratory tract infection one week ago and was recovering well, but over the past day, he developed pain and difficulty with swallowing, fever, and a muffled and hoarse voice. The patient is otherwise healthy and is up-to-date on immunizations. Temperature is 39°C (102°F), blood pressure is 110/56 mmHg, pulse is 121/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient is anxious but is not in respiratory distress. He refuses to extend his neck secondary to pain and will only minimally flex his neck and rotate it. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals swelling without tonsillar enlargement. Bilateral tender cervical lymphadenopathy is present. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following findings indicates the need for advanced imaging?

choices.text: Pain with neck extension and limited range of motion of the neck

questions.solution:
This patient presents with limited range of motion of the neck secondary to pain (torticollis), voice hoarseness, fever, pain with swallowing, and tender cervical lymphadenopathy suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. Limited neck mobility (torticollis) is especially concerning for an infection of the deep space of the pharynx and should prompt advanced imaging including radiographs of the neck and/or computed tomography to rule out a retropharyngeal abscess.         

Peritonsillar and retropharyngeal abscesses can be complications of pharyngitis. Patients with a peritonsillar abscess will exhibit similar historical factors to simple pharyngitis, but on examination will have evidence of peritonsillar swelling and uvular deviation. Patients with a retropharyngeal abscess are typically ill appearing, with evidence of neck immobility, drooling, or respiratory distress dependent on the degree of infection. X-ray of the neck will show widening of the retropharyngeal space or prevertebral soft tissue swelling. CT imaging is performed for a definitive diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Pain with neck extension and limited range of motion of the neck:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Fever:
Incorrect: Fever can be seen with pharyngitis or retropharyngeal abscess, and it does not specifically indicate the need for advanced imaging to rule out a retropharyngeal abscess. 
❌ Recent viral illness:
Incorrect: The history of a recent viral illness in this patient does not specifically indicate a retropharyngeal abscess and the need for advanced imaging, though viral illness typically precedes the development of a retropharyngeal abscess. 
❌ Tender cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Tender cervical lymphadenopathy can be seen with strep pharyngitis and peritonsillar abscess. It does not specifically indicate the need for advanced imaging to rule out a retropharyngeal abscess. 
❌ Odynophagia:
Incorrect: Many patients with pharyngitis develop odynophagia or pain with swallowing. It does not specifically indicate the need for advanced imaging to rule out a retropharyngeal abscess.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought by his parents to the emergency department for evaluation of sore throat, nasal congestion, and sneezing. The patient has been sneezing and has had nasal congestion for the past week. He began complaining of a sore throat two days ago. The patient has a history of asthma but has not been experiencing wheezing. The patient's brother had recently been sick with strep throat. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 109/67mmHg, pulse is 98/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Nasal exam is significant for swollen and edematous turbinates. Examination of the posterior pharynx reveals minimal erythematous changes and a cobblestone-like appearance. There is no tonsillar swelling, and no exudates are present. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of atopy (asthma), nasal congestion, sneezing, and sore throat and the findings of nasal congestion and cobblestoning in the oropharynx are consistent with allergic rhinitis. This patient lacks findings that would indicate strep pharyngitis (i.e., tonsillar swelling and exudates, cervical lymphadenopathy, and fever). He can be diagnosed clinically and treated for allergic rhinitis with cetirizine.         

Pharyngitis, or inflammation of the pharynx, can be caused by non-infectious conditions, like allergic rhinitis, as well as viral and bacterial infections. Pharyngitis is a common pediatric condition that is typically easy to treat, but, in rare cases, it can progress to complications, such as peritonsillar or retropharyngeal abscess.        

Diagnosis of these conditions is often dependent on historical and clinical features, along with risk factor assessment. Patients with allergic pharyngitis may have other signs of allergy (atopy) and can be treated with antihistamines or nasal corticosteroids. Patients with uncomplicated acute pharyngitis caused by infection may present with a sore throat, odynophagia, and malaise. When viral infection is the cause of pharyngitis it is typically self-limited, and patients can be treated with symptomatic care. When pharyngitis is caused by streptococcus species, patients may have fever, tonsillar exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy, and they should be treated with antibiotics. Gonococcal species may cause pharyngitis in sexually active patients. Examination will reveal erythematous changes of the posterior pharynx, with or without exudate and patients should be treated with antibiotics.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer cetirizine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Rapid strep test:
Incorrect: Despite this patient's recent contact with his brother who has strep throat, there are no examination or historical features to suggest strep pharyngitis in this patient. This patient can be diagnosed clinically with allergic rhinitis based on history and physical exam findings.  
❌ Administer amoxicillin:
Incorrect: This patient has no examination or historical features to suggest strep pharyngitis. The history of asthma and signs of nasal congestion and cobblestoning, with lack of fever, tonsillar swelling, exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy suggests allergic rhinitis, which can be treated with an antihistamine.  
❌ Throat culture:
Incorrect: This patient’s examination and historical features suggest allergic rhinitis. Throat culture would be indicated if there were suspicion of strep pharyngitis based on examination of a patient with a negative rapid strep test.  
❌ Administer azithromycin:
Incorrect: Azithromycin could be used to treat sinusitis or strep pharyngitis; however, this patient has no evidence of either. This patient's history of asthma and findings of nasal congestion and cobblestoning, with lack of fever, tonsillar swelling, exudates, and cervical lymphadenopathy suggests allergic rhinitis, which can be treated with an antihistamine.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents to his pediatrician with nasal congestion, fever, and throat pain complaints. His parent reports the patient had an upper respiratory tract infection last week, which seemed to improve, but his symptoms worsened over the past three days. The patient's current vital signs are temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F°), respirations are 16/minute,  pulse is 90/minute, and blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates purulent rhinorrhea. A flexible nasal endoscope is inserted, which confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following correctly describes the anatomic structure implicated in this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The tonsils consist of a group of lymphatic tissues in the posterior pharynx/oropharynx and include pharyngeal, palatine, tubal, and lingual. When the pharyngeal tonsils, or adenoids, become inflamed, the condition is called adenoiditis.

The pharyngeal tonsils typically regress by early puberty; therefore, the majority of patients that present with adenoiditis are prepubescent. A typical history includes a child with a recent viral upper respiratory infection that progresses to fevers, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and halitosis. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, and direct visualization of the inflamed pharyngeal tonsils can be achieved via a laryngeal mirror or nasal endoscope.

Commonly implicated pathogens include those responsible for other upper respiratory tract infections, including Haemophilus influenzae, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes, and Staphylococcus aureus. In addition, environmental allergens and caustic irritation secondary to gastric reflux are known to precipitate adenoiditis.

Option Analysis

✅ Pharyngeal tonsils:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Palatine tonsils:
Incorrect: The palatine tonsils are tonsils located on the left and right sides at the back of the throat, which can often be seen as flesh-colored, pinkish lumps. The palatine tonsils are not the lymphatic tissue associated with acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Thyroid gland:
Incorrect: The thyroid gland lies inferior and anterior to the pharyngeal tonsils--at the level below the cricoid cartilage. The thyroid gland may become enlarged and inflamed for various reasons; however, it is not implicated in cases of acute adenoiditis.  
❌ Tubal tonsils:
Incorrect: The tubal tonsil is located posterior to the Eustachian tube's opening on the nasopharynx's lateral wall. This tonsil may become implicated in cases of eustachian tube dysfunction.  
❌ Parotid gland:
Incorrect: The parotid gland serves as the largest salivary gland and lies on the lateral aspects of the face. The parotid glands cannot be visualized with nasal endoscopy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old-woman presents to the cardiology clinic for follow-up of hypertension. Lately, her blood pressure has been within goal range, but she reports feeling excessively sleepy during the day despite sleeping 7-8 hours nightly. Her partner notes that she snores loudly throughout the night. She has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and takes lisinopril and simvastatin. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 128/82 mmHg. Body mass index (BMI) is 30 kg/m2. On exam, she is alert. She has a deviated nasal septum, mild retrognathia, and enlarged tonsillar tissue. Cardiac examination reveals normal heart sounds with a regular rate and rhythm. Which of the following diagnostic tests will most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 56-year-old woman presents with snoring, poor sleep quality, and excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS), along with risk factors for IOSA including hypertension, enlarged tonsillar tissue, and obesity. The most likely diagnosis is obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Overnight polysomnography (PSG) showing apneas can be used to diagnose OSA.        

An overnight PSG records brain waves, oxygenation, heart rate, respiratory rate, and eye and limb movements in sleep. An apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) measures how often a patient’s breathing stops or slows in sleep. An AHI of at least 5 times per hour is diagnostic for sleep apnea.        

Sleep apnea may occur as the result of an anatomical obstruction to airflow. Risk factors for OSA include obesity, alcohol use or use of other sedatives, smoking, and atrial fibrillation. Anatomic factors, like an increased neck circumference or enlarged structures in the oropharynx may also contribute. Alternatively, central sleep apnea occurs due to lack of respiratory drive, either due to structural brain lesions or use of sedating medications.        

Treatment of both types of sleep apnea includes positive pressure support of the airway, often through continuous or bilevel positive airway pressure (i.e., CPAP or BiPAP).   

Option Analysis

✅ Overnight polysomnography:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Serum iron level:
Incorrect: Iron deficiency can contribute to restless leg symptoms, but this patient’s excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and snoring is concerning for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), which can be diagnosed with an overnight polysomnogram. 
❌ Serum ethanol level:
Incorrect: Excessive daytime sleepiness (EDS) and nocturnal snoring could be the result of alcohol use, but this patient’s symptoms, signs, and physical exam findings of retrognathia, enlarged tonsillar tissue, and obesity are concerning for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). OSA can be diagnosed with an overnight polysomnogram. 
❌ Laryngoscopy:
Incorrect: Craniofacial and upper airway disorders that may be seen with laryngoscopy may increase the risk of OSA, but overnight polysomnography is needed to diagnose OSA.  
❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging:
Incorrect: Though structural brain abnormalities may result in either central or obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), the most appropriate diagnostic test for this patient with signs and symptoms of OSA, and retrognathia, enlarged tonsillar tissue and obesity is an overnight polysomnogram to investigate for apnea.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the office of his maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having dental implant surgery on the lower molars. The patient has inadvertently bitten his inner cheek several times since the surgery due to reduced sensation around the gingiva. The patient also endorses persistent pain in the lower molars, gingiva, chin, and lower lip. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination shows well-appearing dental implants with superficial lacerations over the bilateral inner cheeks. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?

choices.text: Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve

questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve courses into the mandibular canal and provides sensation to the roots of the lower teeth. This nerve exits the skull through the mental foramen as the mental nerve and provides sensation to the lower lip and the skin of the chin. Before entering the mandible, the inferior alveolar nerve gives off a motor branch to the mylohyoid muscle, innervating the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric muscles.

Because of its close relation to the teeth, the inferior alveolar nerve is the most commonly injured nerve during oral surgery. It can be injured during third molar extraction, dental implant surgery, or tumor removal. Injury symptoms include paresthesias, complete numbness, or pain in the teeth, gingiva, chin, and lower lip.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccal nerve  :
Incorrect: The buccal nerve courses into the cheek and pierces the buccinator muscle. This nerve carries sensation from the skin over the cheek and the inner mucous membrane. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lingual Nerve  :
Incorrect: The lingual nerve courses into the tongue and carries sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The incisive branch of the nasopalatine nerve carries sensory information from the front of the hard palate, just behind the incisors. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerve carries sensation from the soft palate. This patient more likely has an injury to the inferior alveolar nerve.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being assaulted at a local bar. He sustained facial trauma, including multiple lacerations and multiple punches to the face. He reports right-sided jaw pain and teeth malalignment. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mmHg. CT of the facial bones demonstrates a right-sided displaced mandibular fracture. The patient is subsequently taken to the operating room for operative repair by otolaryngology. The anesthetist injects a local anesthetic agent between the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe of the right mandible. Injection of an anesthetic into this space is likely to anesthetize which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
An inferior alveolar nerve block is the most common anesthetic procedure performed in dental surgery.  The most critical clinical landmarks used to locate the inferior alveolar nerve include the coronoid notch and the pterygomandibular raphe–the preferred needle insertion site lies between these two landmarks. Successful injection anesthetizes all mandibular teeth to the median plane, the skin and mucous membrane of the lower lip, the labial alveolar mucosa and gingiva, and the skin of the chin.


Other nerves anesthetized during dental procedures are summarized in the table below:  


Option Analysis

❌ Greater palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The greater palatine nerve is best anesthetized by injecting an anesthetic into the greater palatine foramen. This nerve block anesthetizes the palatal mucosa and lingual gingiva posterior to the maxillary canine teeth and underlying palate. This nerve emerges between the 2nd and the 3rd molars.  
❌ Lesser palatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The lesser palatine nerves pass through the lesser palatine foramina posterior to the greater palatine foramen. This nerve supplies sensation to the soft palate, tonsils, and uvula.  
❌ Nasopalatine nerve  :
Incorrect: The nasopalatine nerve can be anesthetized via anesthetic injection into the incisive fossa. Affected tissues include the palatal mucosa, the lingual gingiva and alveolar bone of the six anterior maxillary teeth, and the hard palate.  
✅ Inferior alveolar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anterior superior alveolar nerve  :
Incorrect: The anterior superior alveolar nerve (or anterior superior dental nerve) is a branch of the infraorbital nerve that innervates the anterior teeth and joins the middle superior alveolar nerve to form the superior dental plexus.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department for evaluation of an intractable nosebleed after being hit in the face with a basketball during recess. He does not have any shortness of breath, hemoptysis, or hematemesis. There is no family history of bleeding disorders. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 120/64 mm Hg. The physical exam is notable for clots in the nares, with moderate rebleeding when the clots are dislodged. Which of the following anatomic locations is the most likely site of ongoing bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with uncomplicated epistaxis (nosebleed) following facial trauma. The most common source of bleeding in patients with uncomplicated epistaxis is the Kiesselbach plexus–an area found in the anterior third of the nose. Anastomosis of the following blood vessels occurs in this region:  
  •  Septal branch of the anterior ethmoidal artery 
  •  Lateral nasal branch of the sphenopalatine artery 
  •  Septal branch of superior labial artery (branch of the facial artery) 

Posterior epistaxis, on the other hand, occurs from bleeding in the Woodruff plexus–a collection of arteries in the posteroinferior nasal cavity formed by the anastomoses of the sphenopalatine artery (branch of the maxillary artery) and pharyngeal artery. Posterior epistaxis often presents as difficult to control bleeding from the bilateral nostrils or hemoptysis. Posterior epistaxis is highly associated with brisk bleeding into the posterior pharynx and thus a higher risk of airway compromise or aspiration.




Option Analysis

❌ Inferior turbinate  :
Incorrect: The inferior turbinates, along with superior and middle turbinates, are involved in warming, filtering, and humidifying inspired air. They are unlikely sites of epistaxis.  
❌ Posterolateral wall  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterolateral wall and are the most likely source of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
✅ Kiesselbach plexus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior choanae  :
Incorrect: Branches of the sphenopalatine artery supply the posterior choanae and are the most likely the site of posterior nosebleeds. Epistaxis secondary to injury of the sphenopalatine artery or its branches results in brisk hemorrhage that is difficult to control with direct pressure or specific interventions.  
❌ Middle meatus  :
Incorrect: The middle turbinate over the lateral nasal wall forms the middle meatus, a drainage pathway for the frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinus. It is the most common site for nasal polyps to form but is unlikely to be involved in anterior nasal bleeds.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of jaw pain. The pain started two hours ago after yawning, and now he cannot open or close his mouth. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness over the bilateral periauricular areas with palpable indentation of the preauricular space. The patient’s mouth is open and fixed. The coronoid process of the mandible is prominent and palpable just below the maxilla. Persistent spasm of which of the following muscles contributes to this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an anterior temporomandibular joint (TMJ) dislocation. TMJ dislocations occur when the mandibular condyle travels anteriorly and becomes locked at the superior anterior aspect of the articular eminence of the temporal bone, preventing closure of the mouth. Anterior TMJ dislocations are associated with stretching of the ligaments surrounding the TMJ and severe spasms of the muscles that open and close the mouth (i.e., the masseter, medial and lateral pterygoid, and temporalis muscles).

Anterior dislocations are the most common type of TMJ dislocation and often result from atraumatic mechanisms that involve excessive translational movement of the mandible. Examples include excessive yawning, singing, recurrent vomiting, intubation, or dental procedures. Anterior dislocations often present with jaw pain and decreased range of mandible motion (e.g. mandibular depression or elevation). Posterior dislocations are uncommon, as posterior translation is significantly resisted by the presence of the postglenoid tubercle and the strong intrinsic lateral ligament.  



Option Analysis

❌ Buccinator  :
Incorrect: The buccinator compresses the cheek inwards and pulls the corner of the mouth laterally, which aids in swallowing, mastication, blowing, and sucking. The buccinator contributes to mandibular protrusion and retrusion but not depression.  
❌ Genioglossus  :
Incorrect:  The genioglossus is responsible for tongue protrusion rather than the movement of the mandible.  
✅ Lateral pterygoid  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omohyoid:
Incorrect: The omohyoid travels from the hyoid bone to the clavicle and helps depress the hyoid during speech or swallowing. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.  
❌ Zygomaticus major:
Incorrect: The zygomaticus major pulls the angle of the mouth laterally and superiorly to facilitate smiling. It is not involved in the movement of the mandible.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to her maxillofacial surgeon for follow-up after having her lower third molars removed one week ago. The patient states since the surgery, she has had limited sensation over her lower teeth and accidentally bit the inside of her cheek. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates diminished sensation over the lower teeth and chin. Oral examination demonstrates normal healing of the extraction sites. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
The inferior alveolar nerve, a branch of the mandibular nerve, provides sensation to the lower teeth and terminates as the mental nerve. This nerve is at high risk of injury during molar extractions (particularly third molars or “wisdom teeth”) as it travels through the mandible. Damage to this nerve results in sensory deficits and mental nerve distribution.  

Option Analysis

✅ Inferior alveolar nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient has a sensory deficit along the mandible, not the maxilla.  
❌ Infraorbital nerve:
Incorrect: Damage to the infraorbital nerve manifests with sensory deficits over the lower eyelid, side of the nose, moveable part of the nasal septum, anterior cheek, or upper lip.  
❌ Mental nerve:
Incorrect: The mental nerve is the terminal branch of the inferior alveolar nerve and provides sensory information to the chin and lower lip. This patient’s presentation is consistent with the entire inferior alveolar nerve damage.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of dental pain. The patient has wisdom teeth pain, and it may be infected. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication on a regular basis. The patient has had an allergic reaction to tetracaine in the past while having a laceration repaired. The patient broke out in hives around the injection site. On physical examination, a periapical abscess is identified at the base of the left inferior third molar. Prior to incision and drainage the patient has an inferior alveolar nerve block performed with subsequent reduction in pain. Which of the following medications was most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with dental pain is found to have a periapical abscess, requiring an inferior alveolar nerve block for pain relief. Given his report of an allergic reaction to tetracaine (an ester anesthetic), the most appropriate alternative choice is an amide anesthetic. The only amide anesthetic listed is bupivacaine.    

Local anesthetics are divided based on their chemical structure into two major categories: ester anesthetics and amide anesthetics. All local anesthetics consist of a lipophilic aromatic ring linked to a hydrophilic tertiary amine. Ester anesthetics are named for the ester linkage (-COO-) that connects the aromatic group to the amine group and includes the medications procaine, tetracaine, benzocaine and chloroprocaine.  Conversely, the amide anesthetics lidocaine, mepivacaine, bupivacaine, and ropivacaine consist of an aromatic group connected to an amine group via an amide linkage (-NCO-). One way to remember the difference between these two groups is based on nomenclature--amides have two I’s in their name.    

Notable differences between these two groups are demonstrated in the table below. While extremely rare, the risk of allergic reaction is higher in ester anesthetics, due to possible para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) formation.  



Option Analysis

✅ Bupivacaine :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Procaine:
Incorrect: Procaine is an ester anesthetic, and has a very short duration of action. It is no longer used due to its side effect profile including central nervous system and cardiovascular toxicity. Procaine is also thought to be more likely than other local anesthetics to trigger an allergic reaction, as it is metabolized to para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA).   
❌ Cocaine:
Incorrect: Cocaine is not used as a local anesthetic in current medical practice. The only current medical use of cocaine is via intranasal spray for vasoconstriction in the setting of uncontrolled epistaxis.   
❌ Thiopental:
Incorrect:  Thiopental is a barbiturate medication used for intravenous anesthesia. This medication is not used as a local anesthetic.   
❌ Pentazocine :
Incorrect: Pentazocine is a κ-opioid receptor agonist and μ-opioid receptor weak antagonist or partial agonist used for moderate to severe pain. It is not used as a local anesthetic.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is currently undergoing an adenotonsillectomy secondary to sleep-disordered breathing and recurrent tonsillitis. Intraoperatively, brisk bleeding is noted from the lateral pharyngeal wall after removing the right palatine tonsil. Attempts at cauterization and hemostasis are unsuccessful with continued pulsatile bleeding. The patient’s current vital signs are temperature is 37 C° (98.6 F°), respirations are 18/minute, pulse is 116/minute, and blood pressure is 90/65 mmHg. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Removal of the tonsils is a common procedure performed secondary to recurrent tonsillitis or sleep-disordered breathing. When the palatine tonsils alone are removed, the procedure is referred to as a tonsillectomy; when both the palatine tonsils and the pharyngeal tonsils (adenoids) are removed, it is referred to as an adenotonsillectomy. Typically, some surrounding connective tissue is also removed during these procedures.

During this procedure, several structures are at risk of injury, including the internal carotid artery, glossopharyngeal nerve, and tonsillar artery. The internal carotid artery lies posterior-lateral to the palatine tonsils and is a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding when injured intraoperatively. The superior constrictor muscle lies lateral to the palatine tonsil and immediately deep to these muscles. Damage to this nerve can result in referred otalgia and temporary or rarely permanent alteration in taste.  

Option Analysis

✅ Internal carotid artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. It is more commonly injured during procedures involving the anterior neck due to its more inferior position in the neck.  
❌ External carotid artery:
Incorrect: The external carotid artery branches from the common carotid artery at the fourth or fifth cervical vertebrae level. This structure is not at risk of injury during a tonsillectomy or adenotonsillectomy.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is not at risk of injury during this procedure, given its inferior location in the neck relative to the pharyngeal and palatine tonsils.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The Internal jugular vein is a potential source of injury during this procedure; however, it lies lateral to the internal carotid artery. Moreover, this patient presents with evidence of brisk bleeding consistent with an arterial source.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his ear, nose, and throat surgeon for follow-up after having a parotidectomy due to an invasive mucoepidermoid tumor. The patient reports feeling well, but he has noticed intermittent redness and pain over the area of surgery. In addition, the patient says the site “sweats profusely” every time he becomes hungry or is preparing to eat. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for the finding demonstrated below. Damage to which of the following nerves is most likely implicated in this patient’s disease process?
 

Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with characteristic features of Frey syndrome, a rare neurologic disorder that most commonly occurs following parotid gland surgery. This disease is due to damage and improper regeneration of the auriculotemporal nerve--a branch of the mandibular nerve (V3).

The auriculotemporal nerve contains secretomotor, somatosensory, and vasomotor fibers. The superior component of the nerve provides sensation to the tragus and helix of the ear, the external portion of the tympanic membrane, the posterior temporomandibular joint, and the temple. The inferior component provides autonomic parasympathetic innervation to the parotid gland.

During parotid gland surgery, the auriculotemporal nerve can become damaged with subsequent aberrant reinnervation of postganglionic parasympathetic neurons of denervated sweat glands and cutaneous blood vessels. When this occurs, flushing and sweating can occur in response to mastication and salivation, resulting in Frey syndrome. Pain, numbness, or anesthesia may also occur in the distribution of the auriculotemporal nerve.  

Option Analysis

✅ Auriculotemporal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Zygomatic nerve:
Incorrect: The zygomatic nerve, a branch of the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory information over the cheek and temple. This nerve is unlikely to be damaged based on this patient’s recent surgery.  
❌ Superior alveolar nerve:
Incorrect: The superior alveolar nerve, a branch of the maxillary nerve, provides sensory information to the maxillary teeth, gums, and sinus. This patient does not have evidence of a sensory deficit.  
❌ Facial nerve:
Incorrect: The facial nerve, or cranial nerve VII, provides innervation to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. This patient does not have evidence of facial motor deficits.  
❌ Frontal nerve:
Incorrect: Diminished sensation over the left forehead and scalp may occur with injury to the frontal nerve or its branches. This is likely to occur with a supraorbital rim fracture.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision, stabilized, and admitted for further evaluation and pain control. His initial physical examination demonstrated diffuse contusions and multiple lacerations of the face. Throughout his hospital stay, the patient refuses advanced imaging and is discharged home after two days. Subsequently, the patient returns to the emergency department five days later with continuous rhinorrhea. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates clear rhinorrhea from the right nostril as well as anosmia of the right nostril with the left nostril occluded. Sensation of smell via the left nostril is intact. This patient’s presentation results from injury to which of the following cranial structures?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with loss of smell (anosmia) and clear rhinorrhea following head trauma suggestive of cerebrospinal fluid leak and olfactory nerve injury, secondary to the fracture of the cribriform plate.   

The olfactory nerve transmits olfactory impulses from the olfactory epithelium of the nose to the brain. The central processes of the olfactory nerve make up the numerous nerves which pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone. In severe head injuries, the olfactory bulbs may be torn away from the olfactory nerves. Olfactory nerve fibers may be torn as they pass through a fractured cribriform plate. If the nerve bundles on one side sever, a complete loss of smell will occur on that side; consequently, anosmia may be a clue to a fracture of the cranial base and cerebrospinal fluid rhinorrhea (leakage of the fluid through the nose).  

Option Analysis

❌ Skull base:
Incorrect: Basilar skull fractures can damage CN VIII within the internal acoustic meatus, leading to symptoms of sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, and horizontal nystagmus.  
✅ Cribriform plate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Superior orbital fissure :
Incorrect: The abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI) passes through the superior orbital fissure. Fractures at this location result in an abducens nerve palsy and loss of lateral gaze on the left.   
❌ Jugular foramen:
Incorrect: The jugular foramen is the site of exit for cranial nerves IX, X, and XI; however, these nerves are involved in swallowing, visceral organ function, and trapezius elevation rather than smell.  
❌ Inferior orbital rim:
Incorrect: Fracture of the inferior orbital rim or maxillary fracture can result in the injury to the maxillary nerve (cranial nerve V2), which normally carries the sensory innervation of the left cheek.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a foreign body sensation in the throat. The patient reports she was eating fish soup when she felt a small bone “get stuck in my throat.” After topical lidocaine is applied to the posterior pharynx, a fishbone is retrieved from the piriform recess under video-assisted laryngoscopy. At her follow-up visit several days later, the patient reports she has noticed a slight change in the quality of her voice. Which of the following anatomical structures was most likely injured during removal of the foreign body?
questions.solution:
The piriform recess (or sinus) is a subsite of the hypopharynx. It is a recess on either side of the laryngeal inlet, bounded laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane and medially by the aryepiglottic folds.  It is a common area for foreign bodies to become lodged during swallowing.

The superior laryngeal and its branches lie deep to the mucosa of the piriform recess and may be damaged during lodging or retrieval of foreign bodies from this space. Superior laryngeal nerve damage often manifests with vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality in timbre, pitch, voice projection, and decreased sensation to the laryngeal mucosa.

Damage to the internal laryngeal nerve may result in altered sensation to the laryngeal mucosa, as this nerve only carries sensory information. In contrast, damage to the external laryngeal nerve manifests with changes in voice quality, as this nerve carries motor fibers to the cricothyroid muscle.  

Option Analysis

✅ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN), when damaged, often presents with new-onset hoarseness, changes in vocal pitch, and noisy breathing.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis to both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office to evaluate right ear pain for the past three months. The pain is constant, dull, and associated with recurrent right-sided jaw pain and headache. The pain worsens throughout the day and with chewing. He hears a “cracking sound” while eating. The patient’s partner says that he grinds his teeth at night. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows limited jaw opening and muscle spasms over the lateral right face. Otoscopic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following nerves contributes to this patient’s ear pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s ear pain, headache, and jaw pain are characteristic of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorder. Underlying etiologies of this condition include pathological contraction of the pterygoid muscles secondary to repeated jaw clenching or grinding, misalignment, or trauma. Patients often develop hypersensitivity of the mandibular nerve (CV V3) and subsequent otalgia, given the nerve’s proximity to the TMJ. Classic symptoms include dull, waxing and waning jaw/facial pain, clicking and popping with jaw movement, ear pain, fullness, and tinnitus.

The mandibular nerve, the largest branch of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensation to the TMJ in addition to the floor of the mouth, anterior tongue, and the lower face. In addition, this nerve contributes to sensory innervation to the external auditory canal. Therefore, TMJ disorder can also present with referred ear pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Trigeminal nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypoglossal nerve  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) carries general motor innervation to the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Vagus nerve  :
Incorrect: The auricular branch of the vagus nerve (CN X) carries sensory innervation from the external auditory canal; however, it is not the underlying cause of ear pain in this patient with temporomandibular joint disorder.  
❌ Cervical spinal nerve  :
Incorrect: The cervical spinal nerve is harmed by structural lesions to the cervical spine. More commonly, damage to this nerve results in neck pain/stiffness and arm and shoulder weakness. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.
❌ Vestibulocochlear nerve  :
Incorrect: The vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII) carries auditory and vestibular information from the inner ear. It is not implicated in temporomandibular joint disorder.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the office because of a 1-day history of fever, headache, and bilateral periorbital and mid-facial swelling. The day prior to the onset of the symptoms, the patient had attempted to burst a furuncle in the inner margin of his right nostril. His past medical history is noncontributory, and he does not take any medications. He had last traveled to India 4 months ago. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.5°F), pulse is 66/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 124/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows marked facial and periorbital swelling with bilateral blepharoptosis, chemosis, and proptosis. On fundoscopy, there is no evidence of optic disc swelling. The patient has a full range of eye movements but complains of pain with eye movement. A high-resolution orbital CT with contrast demonstrates bilateral septic cavernous sinus thrombosis. Occlusion of which of the following veins is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fever, headache, and facial swelling following an attempt to burst a nasal furuncle. In combination with CT scan findings, this clinical presentation is suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis.  

The cavernous sinus communicates with the facial vein via the superior ophthalmic vein. The facial vein communicates with the pterygoid venous plexus via the deep facial and inferior ophthalmic veins. Because of these connections and the absence of valves in the facial veins (blood may pass in either direction), an infection of the face may spread to the cavernous sinus and pterygoid venous plexus.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis usually results from infections of the orbit, nasal sinuses, and the superior part of the face that drains into the superior ophthalmic veins. This area is described as the danger triangle (the triangular area from the upper lip to the bridge of the nose is considered the danger triangle of the face).  Infection of the facial veins that may spread to the dural venous sinuses can result from lacerations of the nose or be initiated by squeezing pustules (pimples) on the side of the nose and upper lip.

 


Option Analysis

❌ Supratrochlear vein :
Incorrect: The supratrochlear vein drains the anterior part of the scalp and forehead, where it communicates with the frontal branch of the superficial temporal vein, its contralateral partner, and the supraorbital vein. It does not communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
✅ Superior ophthalmic vein:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Superficial temporal vein :
Incorrect: The superficial temporal vein drains the side of the scalp, superficial aspect of the temporal muscle, and external ear. It begins from a widespread plexus of veins on the side of the scalp and along the zygomatic arch and joins the maxillary vein posterior to the neck of the mandible to form the retromandibular vein. It does not communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
❌ Supraorbital vein:
Incorrect: The supraorbital vein drains the anterior part of the scalp and forehead. It begins in the forehead by anastomosing with the frontal tributary of the superficial temporal vein and terminates as the angular vein at the root of the nose. It does not directly communicate with the facial veins or the cavernous sinuses. 
❌ Deep facial vein:
Incorrect: The deep facial vein drains the infratemporal fossa (most areas supplied by the maxillary artery). It originates at the pterygoid venous plexus and terminates by entering the posterior aspect of the facial vein.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of a firm, nontender swelling over her right cheek for the past five months. The patient does not have a sore throat, runny nose, headache, or fever. Past medical history is noncontributory. The patient smokes one pack of cigarettes daily and drinks one glass of wine after dinner most nights. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows fullness of the right preauricular space. An MRI of the face demonstrates a 3 cm mass of the right parotid gland, which is determined to be neoplastic on a subsequent core-needle biopsy. An elective parotidectomy is performed, and an important nerve embedded within the parotid gland is accidentally injured. Which of the following clinical features is the patient most likely to develop as a result of this injury?

choices.text: Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded
Inability to close the right eye entirely
Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue
Down and out deviation of the right eye
Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field

questions.solution:
This patient was diagnosed with a parotid gland neoplasm and underwent subsequent surgical excision of the parotid gland (parotidectomy). The facial nerve CN VII (parotid plexus) can be injured during parotidectomy or from compression by a parotid gland tumor. Damage to the CN VII or its branches will cause paralysis of the facial muscles, causing them to lose tone. The inferior eyelid can be particularly affected, resulting in an inability to close the eye entirely.

Similarly at risk during parotid pathologies, the auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3), is closely related to the parotid gland and passes superior to it along with the superficial temporal vessels. The auriculotemporal nerve innervates the parotid sheath as well as the overlying skin. Therefore, patients with parotitis (parotid gland inflammation) often experience external auricular pain.


Option Analysis

❌ Deviation of the tongue to the right when protruded  :
Incorrect: The hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) innervates the genioglossus, which is responsible for tongue protrusion. CN XII is most frequently injured during carotid endarterectomy, which can result in ipsilateral genioglossus weakness with a deviation of the tongue toward the ipsilateral side with tongue protrusion. CNXII does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
✅ Inability to close the right eye entirely  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Loss of sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue  :
Incorrect: General sensation over the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is carried by a branch of the trigeminal nerve. This nerve does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Down and out deviation of the right eye  :
Incorrect: Oculomotor nerve (CN III) palsy causes down and out deviation of the eye. CN III does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.  
❌ Visual defect affecting the left half of the visual field  :
Incorrect:  Homonymous hemianopia is a defect that affects half of the visual field due to a contralateral optic nerve (CN II) lesion posterior to the optic chiasm. CN II does not pass through the parotid gland and is therefore unlikely to be injured in this patient.

questions.text: An 85-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a fall. Head CT reveals an acute subdural hemorrhage. A review of medical records shows that she is currently being treated with warfarin for atrial fibrillation. Her INR is found to be 2.3. Which of the following is the next best step in managing this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Warfarin is an anticoagulant that inhibits vitamin K epoxide reductase. This enzyme recycles oxidized vitamin K so that it may be reused in the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X. An immediate solution for deficits in coagulation factors is factor repletion via administration of fresh frozen plasma, prothrombinase complex concentrate, or from other recombinant sources.   

Factor repletion strategies should be utilized when there is an urgent need for warfarin reversal; however, repleted factors have a finite half-life. Sustained warfarin reversal requires the metabolism of warfarin (which takes several days) or supplementation with vitamin K, which takes several hours to take effect.  

Option Analysis

❌ Stop warfarin therapy:
Incorrect: Stopping warfarin therapy will take several days to reduce a patient's risk for further bleeding. 
❌ Administer oral vitamin K:
Incorrect: Vitamin K takes several hours to reverse anticoagulation, as it takes time for new factors to be synthesized. This effect is largely independent of administration orally or intravenously.   
❌ Administer intravenous vitamin K:
Incorrect: Vitamin K takes several hours to reverse anticoagulation, as it takes time for new factors to be synthesized. This effect is largely independent of administration orally or intravenously.   
✅ Administer fresh frozen plasma (FFP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administer platelets:
Incorrect: This patient's increased risk of bleeding results from a coagulation factor deficit–not from a deficit in platelet number or function.   
❌ Administer protamine sulfate:
Incorrect: Protamine sulfate is the medication of choice for reversing the anticoagulant effects induced by heparin.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male comes to the clinic complaining of fatigue, dizziness, and shortness of breath. Past medical history includes type II diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease, for which he has been on dialysis for the last 4 years. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mmHg. Physical exam shows pallor of the conjunctiva and finger nail beds. Laboratory tests are obtained and the results are shown below.  



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treating this patient’s hematological abnormality?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic kidney disease has lab findings showing normocytic anemia, low reticulocyte count (< 2%), low serum iron, high ferritin levels, and low total iron binding capacity (TIBC). He has anemia of chronic disease due to chronic kidney disease (CKD).  

Anemia of chronic disease is caused by increased hepcidin release from the liver. Hepcidin binds to a transmembrane protein called ferroportin, which is found on intestinal mucosal cells, thus blocking iron absorption from the gut and release from macrophages where it is stored. As a result, although there is iron in the body, it is trapped within macrophages, and serum iron levels are decreased. The bone marrow is unable to produce adequate levels of erythrocytes, resulting in anemia. Iron studies can aid in diagnosis and differentiate anemia of chronic disease from other iron-related pathologies.
